The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: ART OF CONTENTMENT; WITH SEVERAL ENTERTAINING PIECES OF Poetry, DESCRIPTIVE OF THE PRESENT TIMES, IN THE U. States of America.
By JOHN SEARSON, Formerly a Merchant of Philadelphia.

q.l: We to ourselves may all our wishes grant,
For nothing coveting, we nothing want:
They cannot want, who wish not to have more,
Contented minds may smile when counted poor.

To evince this, I Å¿hall inÅ¿iÅ¿t upon theÅ¿e particulars. FirÅ¿t, That God is debtor to man, and therefore whatever he affords to any, it is upon bounty, not of right, a benevolence not a due. Secondly, That this bounty is not Å¿trait or narrow, confined to Å¿ome few particular perÅ¿ons, and wholly over-Å¿kipping the reÅ¿t, but more or leÅ¿s univerÅ¿ally diffuÅ¿ed to all. So that he who has the leaÅ¿t, cannot juÅ¿tly Å¿ay but he has been liberally dealt with. Thirdly, That if we compare our bleÅ¿Å¿ings with our allays, our good things with our evil, we will find our good far Å¿urmounting. Fourthly, That we Å¿hall find them yet more Å¿o, if we compare them with the good we have done; as on the contrary, we Å¿hall find our afflictions Å¿carce diÅ¿cernable if balanced with our Å¿ins. Fifthly, That as God is rector of the univerÅ¿e, Å¿o it appertains to him to make Å¿uch allotments, Å¿uch diÅ¿tributions as may beÅ¿t preÅ¿erve the Å¿tate of the whole, Sixthly, That God notwithÅ¿tanding that univerÅ¿al care, has alÅ¿o a peculiar aspect on every particular perÅ¿on, and diÅ¿poÅ¿es to him what he diÅ¿cerns beÅ¿t for him in Å¿pecial. Seventhly, If we compare our adverÅ¿ities with thoÅ¿e
of other men, we Å¿hall always find Å¿omething that equals, if nnot exceeds our own. All theÅ¿e are certain irrefragable truths, and there is none of them Å¿ingle, but may, if well preÅ¿t upon the mind, charm it into a calmneÅ¿s and reÅ¿ignation; but when there is Å¿uch a conÅ¿piration of arguments, it muÅ¿t be a very obÅ¿tinate perverÅ¿eneÅ¿s that can reÅ¿iÅ¿t them: Or Å¿hould they Å¿ail to enforce a full conviction, will yet introduce thoÅ¿e Å¿ubÅ¿idiary proofs, which I have to alledge, Å¿o advantageouÅ¿ly, as will, being put altogether, amount unto perfect and uncontrollable evidence.

div.head: SECT. II
Of God's AbÅ¿olute Sovereignty.
div.p:
THE firÅ¿t propoÅ¿ition that God is debtor to no man, is too clear and apparent to require much of illuÅ¿tration: For as he is a free agent, and may act as he pleaÅ¿es, Å¿o he is the Å¿ole proprietary, and can wrongfully detain from none, becauÅ¿e all original right is in himÅ¿elf. This has been Å¿o much acknowledged by the blindeÅ¿t heathens, that none of them durÅ¿t make inÅ¿olent addreÅ¿Å¿es to their gods, challenge any thing of them as of debt, but by Å¿acrifices and prayers owned their dependance and wants, and implored Å¿upplies. And Å¿ure, chriÅ¿tianity teaches us not to be more Å¿aucy. If thoÅ¿e deities who owed their very being to their votaries, were yet acknowledged to be the Å¿pring and Å¿ource of all, we can with no pretence deny it to that Å¿uprenÅ¿e power, in whom we live, move, and have our being, Acts xvii. 28. For if it were merely an act of his choice to give us a being, all his Å¿ubÅ¿equent bounties can have no other original than his own good pleaÅ¿ure. We could put no obligation upon God before we were; and when we began to be, we were his creatures, and Å¿o by the moÅ¿t indiÅ¿putable right owe ourÅ¿elves to him, but can have no antecedent
title on which to claim any thing from him: So that the apoÅ¿tle might well make the challenge which he doth on God's behalf, Who hath given any thing unto him, and it Å¿hall be recompenced to him again? Rom. xi. 35.

2. Now ordinary diÅ¿cretion teaches us, not to be too bold in our expectation from one to whom we can plead no right. It has as little of prudence as modeÅ¿ty, to preÅ¿s impudently upon the bounty of a patron, and does but give him temptation (at leaÅ¿t pretence) to deny. And if it be thus with men, who poÅ¿Å¿ibly may sometimes have an intereÅ¿t, Å¿ometimes a vanity to oblige: it muÅ¿t be much more Å¿o towards God, who cannot be in want of us, and therefore need not buy us: Our good, as the PÅ¿almiÅ¿t Å¿peaks, extends not to him, PÅ¿al. xvi. 2. He has fundamental right in that little we are, which will Å¿tand good tho' it Å¿hould never be corroborated by greater benefits. With what an humble baÅ¿hfulneÅ¿s should we then Å¿ue for any thing, who have no argument to invite the leaÅ¿t donation, being already Å¿o pre-engaged, that we cannot mortgage Å¿o much as ourÅ¿elves in conÅ¿ideration of any new favor? And Å¿urely, extravagant hopes do very ill befit people in this condition. We Å¿ee the modeÅ¿ty
of good MephiboÅ¿heth, tho' he was by a Å¿landerous accuÅ¿ation outed of half the eÅ¿tate David given him, yet upon a reflection that he derived it all from his good pleaÅ¿ure, diÅ¿puted not the Å¿entence, but cheerfully reÅ¿igned to the Å¿ame diÅ¿poÅ¿ure, from which he received it, Å¿aying, Yea, let him take all, 2 Sam, xix. 30. A rare example, and fit for imitation, as being adapted to the preÅ¿ent caÅ¿e, not only in that one circumÅ¿tance of his having received all from the king, but alÅ¿o in that of the attainder of his blood: which he confeÅ¿Å¿es in the former part of the 28th verÅ¿e, For all of my father's houÅ¿e were but dead men before my Lord. And alas! may we not Å¿ay the very Å¿ame? Was not our whole race tainted in our firÅ¿t parent? So that if God had not the primary title of vaÅ¿Å¿alage, he would in our fall have acquired that of confiÅ¿cation and eÅ¿cheat. And can we think ourÅ¿elves then in terms to capitulate, and make our own conditions, and expect God Å¿hould humour us in all our wild demands?

3. This is indeed to keep up that old rebellion of our progenitor, for that conÅ¿iÅ¿ted in a diÅ¿content with that portion God had aÅ¿Å¿igned him, and coveting what he had reÅ¿trained him. Nay indeed it comes up to the height of the devil's propoÅ¿al,
the attempting to be as God, Gen. iii. 5. For 'tis an endeavor to wreÅ¿t the management out of his hands, to Å¿upercede his authority of diÅ¿penÅ¿ing to us, and to carve for ourÅ¿elves. This is Å¿o mad an inÅ¿olence, that were it poÅ¿ible to Å¿tate a caÅ¿e exactly parallel between man and man, it would raiÅ¿e the indignation of any that but pretended to ingenuity. Yet this is, without hyperbole, the true meaning of every murmuring repining thought we entertain.

4. But as bad as it is, who is there of us, that can in this particular Å¿ay, We have made our hearts clean? Prov. xx. 9. 'Tis true we make Å¿ome formal acknowledgment Å¿ometimes that we receive all from God's gift: CuÅ¿tom teaches us from our infancy, after every meal we eat, to give him thanks (though even that is now thought too much reÅ¿pect, and begins to be diÅ¿carded as unfaÅ¿hionable:) yet Å¿ure he cannot be thought to do that in earneÅ¿t, that has all the time of his eating been grumbling that his table abounds not with Å¿uch delicacies as his neigbors. And yet at this rate God knows are moÅ¿t of our thanÅ¿kgivings. Indeed we have not Å¿o much ordinary civility to God, as we have to men. The common proverb
teaches us, not to pry too curiouÅ¿ly into the blemiÅ¿hes of what is given us; but on God's gifts we fit as cenÅ¿ors, nicely examine every thing which is in any way diÅ¿agreeable to our fancies, and as if we dealt with him under the notion of chapmen, diÅ¿parage it, as Solomon Å¿ays, buyers uÅ¿e to do, It is naught, it is naught Å¿aith the buyer, Prov. xx. 14. Nay we Å¿eem yet more abÅ¿urdly to change the Å¿cene, and as if God were to make oblations to us, we as critically obÅ¿erve the detects of his benefactions, as the Levitical prieÅ¿ts were to do thoÅ¿e of the Å¿acrifice, and (like angry Deities) Å¿cornfully reject, whatever does not perfectly anÅ¿wer our wanton appetites.

5. And now, Å¿hould God take us at our words, withdraw all thoÅ¿e bleÅ¿Å¿ings which we Å¿o faÅ¿tidiouÅ¿ly deÅ¿piÅ¿e, what a condition were we in? Tis Å¿ure we have nothing to plead in reverÅ¿e of that Judgment. There is nothing in it againÅ¿t juÅ¿tice; for he takes but his own. This he intimates to IÅ¿real, HoÅ¿. ii. 9. I will return and take away my corn in the time thereof, and my wine in the Å¿eaÅ¿on thereof, and will recover my wool and my flax; In which he aÅ¿Å¿erts his own property, My corn, my wine, &c. and recalls them to the remembrance that they were but uÅ¿ufructuaries. And 'tis as evident that our tenure is but the same. Nay this proceeding would not be repugnant
even to mercy, for even that is not obliged Å¿till to proÅ¿titute itÅ¿elf to our contempt. I am Å¿ure Å¿uch a toleration is beyond all the meaÅ¿ures of human lenity. Should any of us offer an alms to an indigent wretch, and he when he Å¿ees 'tis Å¿ilver, Å¿hould murmur and exclaim that it is not gold, would we not draw back our hand, and reÅ¿erve our charity for a more worthy object? 'Tis true indeed, God's thoughts are not as our thoughts, nor our narrow bowels equal meaÅ¿ures for the devine compaÅ¿Å¿ion; and we experimentally find that his long-Å¿uffering infinitely exceeds ours; yet we know he does in the parable of the lord and the Å¿ervant, Matt. xxviii. declare, that he will proportion his mercy by ours, in that inÅ¿tance; and we have no promiÅ¿e that he will not do it in this; nay we have all reaÅ¿on to expect he Å¿hould: For Å¿ince his wiÅ¿dom prompts him to do nothing in vain, and all his bounty to us is deÅ¿igned to make us happy, when he Å¿ees that end utterly fruÅ¿trated by our diÅ¿contents, to what purpoÅ¿e Å¿hould he continue that to which we will be never the better for?

6. BeÅ¿ides tho' he be exceedingly patient, yet he is not negligent or inÅ¿enÅ¿ible; he takes particular notice, not only with what diligence we employ, but with what affections we reÅ¿ent every of his bleÅ¿Å¿ings.
And as ingratitude is a voice odious to man Å¿o it is extremely provoking to God; Å¿o that in this Å¿enÅ¿e alÅ¿o, the words of our Saviour are moÅ¿t true, From him that hath not (i. e.) that hath not a grateful Å¿enÅ¿e and value, Å¿hall be taken away even that he hath Mat. xxv. 29. But we may find a threatning of this kind, more expreÅ¿s to IÅ¿real. BecauÅ¿e thou Å¿ervedÅ¿t not the Lord thy God with gladneÅ¿s, and with joyfulneÅ¿s of heart, for the abundance of all things, therefore Å¿hall thou Å¿erve thine enemies, whom the Lord God will Å¿end among thee, in hunger, and in thirÅ¿t, and in nakedneÅ¿s, and in want of all things, Deut. xxviii. 27. A Å¿ad and diÅ¿mal inverÅ¿ion, yet founded wholly in the want of that cheerful recognition which God expected from them. And if IÅ¿rael, the lot of his inheritance, that people whom he had Å¿ingled out from all the nations of the world, could thus forfeit his favor by unthankfulneÅ¿s, Å¿ure none of us can Å¿uppoÅ¿e we have any Å¿urer entail of it. In a word, as God loves a cheerful giver, Å¿o he alÅ¿o loves a cheerful receiver; one that complies with his end in beÅ¿towing, by taking a juÅ¿t complacence in his gifts. But the querulous and unÅ¿atisfied, reproach his bounty; accuÅ¿e him of â€¢ illiberality and narrowneÅ¿s of mind. So that he Å¿eems even in his honor engaged to bring them to a righter
apprehenÅ¿ion of him, and by a deprivation teach them the value of thoÅ¿e good things which they could not learn by the enjoyment.

7. If therefore ingenuity and gratitude cannot, yet at leaÅ¿t let prudence and Å¿elf-love engage us againÅ¿t this Å¿in of Murmuring, which we Å¿ee does abundantly juÅ¿tify the character the wiÅ¿e man gives, when he tells us, 'tis unprofitable, WiÅ¿d. i. 11, he might have Å¿aid pernicious alÅ¿o; for Å¿o it evidently is in it's effects. Let us then arm ourÅ¿elves againÅ¿t it, and to that purpoÅ¿e impreÅ¿s deeply upon our minds the preÅ¿ent conÅ¿ideration. That God owes us nothing, and that whatever we receive is an alms, and not a tribute. Diogenes being aÅ¿ked what wine drank the moÅ¿t pleaÅ¿ant, anÅ¿wered, That which is drank at another's coÅ¿t. And this circumÅ¿tance we can never miÅ¿s of to recommend our good things to us: For be they little or much, they come gratis. When therefore in a pettiÅ¿h mood we find ourÅ¿elves apt to charge God fooliÅ¿hly, and to think him Å¿trait-handed towards us, let us imagine we hear God expoÅ¿tulating with us, as the houÅ¿holder in the parable,
â€¢ riend I do thee no wrong: is it not lawful fo â€¢ me to do what I will with my own? Mat.
xx. 15. If God have not the right of diÅ¿p â€¢â€¢ Å¿ing, let us find out those that have, and Å¿ee how much better we Å¿hall Å¿peed: But if he hath let us take heed of diÅ¿puting with him: We that Å¿ubÅ¿iÅ¿t merely by his favor, had need court and cheriÅ¿h it by all the arts of humble obÅ¿ervance. Every man is ready to Å¿ay how ill beggary and pride do agree. The firÅ¿t qualification we cannot put off. O let us not provide it of the other Å¿o inconvenient, Å¿o odious an adjunct. Let us leave off preÅ¿cribing to God (which no ingenious man would do to an earthly benefactor) and Å¿et us betake ourÅ¿elves to a more holy and Å¿ucceÅ¿sful policy, the acknowledgment of paÅ¿t mercies, and our own unworthineÅ¿s. This was Jacob's method, I am not worthy of the leaÅ¿t of all the mercies, and of all the truth which thou haÅ¿t Å¿hewed unto thy Å¿ervant: for with my Å¿taff I paÅ¿Å¿ed over this Jordan and now I am become two bands; and with this humble preface he introduces his petition for reÅ¿cue in his preÅ¿ent diÅ¿treÅ¿s, Deliver me I pray thee from the hand of my brother, &c. Gen. xxx. 10, 11. An excellent pattern of divine rhetoric, which the Å¿ucceÅ¿s demonÅ¿trates to have been very prevalent. And we cannot tranÅ¿cribe better copy, to render our deÅ¿ires as Å¿ucceÅ¿sful. Indeed we are Å¿o utterly deÅ¿titute of all arguments from ourÅ¿elves, that we
can make no reaÅ¿onable form of addreÅ¿s, if we found it not in Å¿omething of God; and there is nothing even in him adapted to our purpoÅ¿e, but his mercy: nor can that be Å¿o advantageouÅ¿ly urged by any thing, as by the former inÅ¿tances it has given of itÅ¿elf: for as God only is fit to be a precedent to himÅ¿elf, Å¿o he loves to be Å¿o. Thus we find, not only MoÅ¿es, but God often recollecting his miraculous favors towards IÅ¿rael, as an argument to do more: Let us therefore accoÅ¿t him in his own way, and by a frequent and grateful recounting of his former mercies, engage him to future. Nor need we be at a loÅ¿s for matter of Å¿uch recollection, if we will but Å¿eriouÅ¿ly conÅ¿ider what we have already received, which is the Å¿ubject of the next Å¿ection.

div.head: SECT. III.
Of God's unlimited Beauty.
div.p: IT is the kown character of an unworthy nature, to write injuries in marble, and benefits in duÅ¿t; and however Å¿ome (as Senaca well obÅ¿erves) may acquit themÅ¿elves of this imputation as to man, yet Å¿carce any do Å¿o in relation to God. 'Tis true indeed the charge muÅ¿t be a little varied; for God neither will nor can do us injury: Yet we receive any thing that is adverÅ¿e with Å¿uch a reÅ¿entment as if it were, and engrave that in our memories with indelible characters, whilÅ¿t his great and real benefits are either not at all obÅ¿erved, or with Å¿o tranÅ¿ient an advertence, that the compariÅ¿on of duÅ¿t is beyond our pitch, and we may be more properly Å¿aid to write them in water. Nay Å¿o far are we from keeping records and regiÅ¿ters of his favors, that even thoÅ¿e Å¿tanding and fit ones which Å¿enÅ¿e can prompt us to, (without the aid of our memories) cannot obtain our notice.

2. Were it not thus, it were impoÅ¿Å¿ible for men to be Å¿o perpetually in the complaining key, as if their voices were capable of no other Å¿ound. One wants this,
and another that, and a third Å¿omething beyond them both, and Å¿o
ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰
when all this while every one of them enjoys a multitude of good things without any remark. That very breath wherewith they utter their complaints, is a bleÅ¿Å¿ing, and a fundamental one too: for, if God Å¿hould withdraw that, they were incapable of whatÅ¿oever elÅ¿e they either have, or deÅ¿ire. 'Tis true that Å¿ome men's impatience hath riÅ¿en Å¿o high, as to caÅ¿t away life, becauÅ¿e it was not cloathed with all the circumÅ¿tances, they wiÅ¿hed. Yet theÅ¿e are rare inÅ¿tances, and do only Å¿hew Å¿uch men's depraved judgment of things. A rich jewel is not the leÅ¿s valuable, becauÅ¿e a mad man in his raving Å¿it flings it into the fire: But as to the generality of men, the Devil (though a liar) gave a true account of their Å¿enÅ¿e, when he Å¿aid, Skin for Å¿kin, and that a man hath, will he give for his life, Job. II. 4. And though perhaps in an angry fit many men have with Jonas, Chap. iv. 3. wiÅ¿hed to die, yet ten to one, Å¿hould death then come, they would be as willing to divert it, as was the man in the Apologue, who wearied with his burden of Å¿ticks, flung it down and called for death; but when he came, owned no other occaÅ¿ion for him, but to be helped up again with his bundle. I dare in this appeal to the experience
of thoÅ¿e, who have Å¿eemed very weary of life, whether when any Å¿udden danger has Å¿urpriÅ¿ed them, it has not as Å¿uddenly altered their mind, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ and made them have a greater deÅ¿ire for life, than before they abhorred it. 'Tis the common Å¿aying, as long as there is life there is hope: it is Å¿o, as to Å¿ecular concerns, for what Å¿trange revolutions do we often Å¿ee in the age of man? From what deÅ¿picable beginnings have many arrived to the moÅ¿t Å¿plendid conditions? Of which we have divers modern as well as ancient inÅ¿tances.

Indeed 'tis admirable to Å¿ee what time &c. induÅ¿try will (with God's bleÅ¿Å¿ing) effect. But there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wiÅ¿dom in the grave, EC. ix. 10. we can improve no more when we are once tranÅ¿planted thither.

3. But this is yet much more conÅ¿iderable in reÅ¿pect of our Å¿piritual Å¿tate. Our life is the day wherein we are to work, John ix. (yea to work out Salvation:) but when the night comes (when death overtakes) no man can work. Now alas when it is conÅ¿idered how much of this day the moÅ¿t of us have Å¿tood idle till the Å¿ixth or ninth hour, it will be our concern not to have our day cloÅ¿e before the eleventh.
Nay alas it is yet worÅ¿e with us: We have not only been idle, but very often ill buÅ¿ied: Å¿o that we have a great part of our time to unravel, and that is not to be done in a moment. For though our works may fitly enough be repreÅ¿ented by the Prophet's compariÅ¿on of a Å¿pider's web, IÅ¿a. lix. 5. yet they want the beÅ¿t property even of that; they cannot be Å¿o Å¿oon undone. Vices that are radicated by time and cuÅ¿tom, lie too deep to be lightly Å¿wept away. It is no eaÅ¿y thing to perÅ¿uade ourÅ¿elves to the will of parting with them. Many violences we muÅ¿t offer to ourÅ¿elves, a long and Å¿trict courÅ¿e of mortification muÅ¿t be gone through, e'er we can find in our hearts to bid them begone: And yet when we do Å¿o, they are not Å¿o tractible us the Centurions Å¿ervants. They will indeed come when ever we bid them, but they will Å¿carce go Å¿o: they muÅ¿t be expelled by force and by Å¿low degrees; we muÅ¿t Å¿ight for every inch of ground we gain from them: And as God would not aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t the IÅ¿raelites to Å¿ubdue the Canaanites at once, Deut. vii. 22. Å¿o neither ordinarily does he, us to maÅ¿ter perfectly our corruptions. Now a proceÅ¿s of this difficulty is not to be diÅ¿patched on a Å¿udden. And yet this is not all our taÅ¿k, for we have not only ill habits to extirpate, but we have alÅ¿o good ones to acquire: It is
not a mere negative virtue will Å¿erve our turns, nor will empty lamps enter us into the marriage-chamber, Mat. xxv. 10. He muÅ¿t add to our faith virtue, and to virtue knowledge, and to knowledge temperance, &c.
â€¢ Pet. i. 15.

4. And now I would deÅ¿ire the Reader Å¿eriouÅ¿ly to conÅ¿ider, whether he can upon good grounds tell himÅ¿elf that this Å¿o difficult, (and yet Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary) a work is effectually wrought in him. If it be, he is a happy man, and can with no pretence complain of any external want: (he that is fed with Manna, muÅ¿t be Å¿trangely perverÅ¿e if he murmur for a belly-full of leeks and onions, Num. xi. 15.) But on the contrary, he owes infinite thanks to God, that has Å¿pared him time for this important buÅ¿ineÅ¿s, and did not put a period to his natural life, before he had begun a Å¿piritual. For I fear there are among the beÅ¿t of us few of Å¿o entire an innocence, but they may remember Å¿ome, either habits or acts of fin, in which it would have been dreadful for them to have been Å¿natched away. And then how comprehenÅ¿ive, how prolific a mercy has life been to them, when it has carried eternity in its womb, and their continuance on earth has qualified them for heaven? Neither are Å¿uch perÅ¿ons only to look on it as
a bleÅ¿Å¿ing in the retroÅ¿pect, as it relates to the paÅ¿t, but alÅ¿o in the preÅ¿ent and future; which if they continue to employ well, does not only confirm, but advance their reward. BeÅ¿ides God may pleaÅ¿e by them to glorify himÅ¿elf, make them inÅ¿trumental to his Å¿ervice; which as it is the greateÅ¿t honor, Å¿o it is alÅ¿o the greateÅ¿t Å¿atisfaction to a good heart. He Å¿hews himÅ¿elf too mercenary that Å¿o longs for his reward, as to grow impatient of his attendance: He that loves God, thinks himÅ¿elf bleÅ¿t in the opportunity of doing work, as well as in receiving wages. Thus we Å¿ee how life is under all theÅ¿e aÅ¿pects, a mercy to a pious man, and Å¿uch as not only obliges him to contentment, but gratitude.

5. But Å¿uppoÅ¿ing a man cannot give this comfortable account of his life, but is conÅ¿cious that he has Å¿pent it to a very different purpoÅ¿e, yet does not that at all leÅ¿Å¿en his obligations to God, who meant he Å¿hould have employed it better, and that he has not done Å¿o is merely his own fault. Nay indeed the worÅ¿e his Å¿tate is, the greater mercy it is, that God has not made it irreverÅ¿ible, that he has not cut him off at once from the earth, and the poÅ¿Å¿ibility of Heaven too, but affords him
yet a longer day, if yet be will hear his voice, PÅ¿al. xcv. 7. This long-Å¿uffering is one of the moÅ¿t tranÅ¿cendant acts of divine goodneÅ¿s, and therefore the ApoÅ¿tle rightly Å¿tiles it the the riches of his goodneÅ¿s, and long Å¿uffering, and forbearance, Rom. ii. 4. And Å¿o at laÅ¿t we commonly acknowledge it, when we have worn it out, and can no longer receive advantage by it. What a value does a gaÅ¿ping deÅ¿pairing Å¿oul put upon a Å¿mall parcel of that time, which before he knew not how faÅ¿t enough to Å¿quander? Oh that men would Å¿et the Å¿ame eÅ¿timate on it before: and then certainly as it would make them better huÅ¿bands of it, Å¿o it would alÅ¿o render them more thankful for it, Accounting that the long-Å¿uffering of our Lord is Å¿alvation, 2. Pet. iii. 15.

6. Indeed did men but rightly compute the benefit of life upon this Å¿core, all Å¿ecular encumbrances and uneaÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿es of it would be overwhelmed, and Å¿tand only as cyphers in the account. What a Å¿hame is it then that we Å¿hould Å¿pend our breath in Å¿ighs and out-cries? which if we would employ to thoÅ¿e nobler ends for which it was given, would Å¿uperÅ¿ede our complaints, and make us confeÅ¿s we were well dealt with: that on life (though bare and Å¿tripped of all outward acceÅ¿Å¿aries) is
gives us for a prey, Jer. xlv. 5. And indeed he that has yet the great work of life to do, can very ill Å¿pare time or Å¿orrow to beÅ¿tow upon the regretting any temporal diÅ¿treÅ¿s, Å¿ince his whole Å¿tock is little enough to bewail and repair his neglects of his eternal concerns. Were our lives therefore deÅ¿titute of all outward comfort, nay were they nothing but a Å¿cene of perpetual diÅ¿aÅ¿ters, yet this one advantage of life would infinitely outweigh them all, and render our murmuring very inexcuÅ¿able.

7. But God has not put this to the utmoÅ¿t trial, has never placed any man in Å¿uch a Å¿tate of unmixed calamity, but that he Å¿till affords many and great comforts: he finds it fit Å¿ometimes to diminiÅ¿h Å¿ome of our outward comforts, and perhaps imbitter others, but he never takes all way. This muÅ¿t be acknowledged, it we do but conÅ¿ider how many things there are in which the whole race of mankind do in common partake. The four elements, fire and water, air and earth, do not more make up every man's compoÅ¿ition, that they Å¿upply his needs: the whole hoÅ¿t of heaven, the Å¿un, moon, and Å¿tars, MoÅ¿es, will tell us, are by God divided to all nations under the whole heaven, Deut. iv. 19. ThoÅ¿e reÅ¿plendent bodies,
equally afford their light and influence to all. The Å¿un Å¿hines as bright on the poor cottage, as on the moÅ¿t magnificent palace; and the Å¿tars have their benign aÅ¿pects, as well for him that is behind the mill, as for him that Å¿itteth on the throne, Exod. xi. 5. Property (the great incendiary below) breeds no confuÅ¿ion in thoÅ¿e celeÅ¿tial orbs, but they are every man's treaÅ¿ure, yet no man's peculiar, (as if they meant to teach us, that our love of appropriation deÅ¿cends not from above, James iii. 15, is no heavenly quality.)

8. And as they make no diÅ¿tinction of the ranks and degrees of men, Å¿o neither do they of their virtues. to them.
